title: Make soldiers salesmen for British weapons, says defence trade group
text:
Tip : Use comma (,) to separate multiple quotes. Learn more... 
Wed, Sep 9, 2015, 19:28 BST - UK Markets closed Make soldiers salesmen for British weapons, says defence trade group By Alan Tovey | Telegraph – 10 minutes ago 449.70 +5.90 
Ministry of Defence should be ordered to help sell British arms to foreign buyers, says weapon makers' trade association 
Soldiers, sailors and pilots should sell British-made weapons to help boost exports, according to the defence industry association. 
Having military staff who actually use the systems advising potential customers would increase the chances of securing foreign sales, according to ADS, which represents the country’s aerospace, defence and security businesses. 
Speaking as the Government prepares its defence review, which will set out military priorities, and France’s Rafale fighter landed a series of export deals that the Eurofighter Typhoon in which BAE Systems (LSE: BA.L - news ) is a partner missed out on, ADS chief executive Paul Everitt said the industry needs formal support from the forces. 
“One thing from the defence review which would make a difference to exports is for the Ministry of Defence to have supporting exports as a core task,” he said. “The objective is to have their staff alongside ours.” 
Defending the potential burden of such a move on already overstretched military budgets, Mr Everitt said: “Defence is a market that is like no other and this is not about industry demanding free advertising from the military. 
“Sales of defence equipment to countries are about building long-term strategic relationships with them which are good for Britain. Countries buying defence equipment such as the Typhoon do not see the sale as buying from a company, they see it as buying from Britain.” 
He added that Britain is lagging behind rivals such as France in its efforts to promote defence exports and that the US the world’s biggest military exporter has the most effective system, with the products effectively being sold by the military . 
Although ADS has not looked into how much its proposals would cost, Mr Everitt said the financial impact would be marginal to the MoD and would formalise the current haphazard process, as well as ultimately strengthening the forces through the UK having a stronger economy. 
“Buyers want to talk to the people who use the equipment and service the equipment, not businessmen,” he added. 
The chief executive of one leading British defence company that derives a large proportion of its revenue from exports said: "We get pretty good support from UKTI but if serving troops were to act for us that would give an incredible boost. 
"As we become less and less dependent on the MoD for revenues and look abroad for more of our sales, any extra support would be welcome. We recently closed a sale where we had ex-military staff working on the sale and their recent experience of using the products in an operational environment was invaluable - there is no substitute for that sort of insight." 
The defence chief added that he thought serving troops working on export sales would deliver a "significant flowback" to the MoD through a stronger economy. 
The call came as the trade body reported that UK annual sales of security products rose by £500m to £8.5bn in 2014, though the amount of exports was relatively flat at £3.4bn. 
According to ADS data, Britain’s total export sales of security systems ranging from sensors and alarms to communications and anti-hacking software and more traditional defence products such as aircraft and weapons was £13bn in 2013, up from £11.5bn the year before. 
A spokesman for the MoD said: “The UK is the second-biggest defence exporter in the world with only the US ahead of us. The Government continues to work closely with the UK defence sector in pursuit of export opportunities, providing wide ranging and effective support.”
